chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So quick recap of what we did last time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Last time we talked about strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we talked about strings, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are the strings that are used to create

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and create a string that is used to create a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Quick recap of what we did last time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Last time we talked about strings as a new object type,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as sequences of characters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we introduced two new concepts

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that allowed us to write slightly more complicated

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we introduced branching with these keywords if, l, if, else.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And branching allowed us to write programs that us

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as programmers could introduce decisions into our programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we introduced two different kinds of loops,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: while loops and for loops.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And those also added a little bit of complexity

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to our programs.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Today we're going to talk a little bit more about strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to see a couple more operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you can do on strings and string objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we're going to talk about three

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different algorithms.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: A guess and check algorithm, an approximate solution algorithm,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and a bisection method algorithm.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so let's dive right in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We'll talk a little bit about strings first.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So strings, we thought of them as sequences of characters,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: case sensitive, as we saw in programs we wrote last lecture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And strings are objects, and we can do all of these operations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: on string objects, like test if they're equal, less than,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: greater than, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Turns out we can do more than just concatenate two strings

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: together or do these little tests on them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to start introducing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the idea of a function or a procedure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to see more about functions

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and how you can write your own functions next lecture.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But for today, you can think of a function

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as sort of a procedure that does something for you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Someone already wrote this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first one we're going to look at

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is a pretty popular function.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And when applied on a string, this function called len

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: will tell you the length of a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's going to tell you how many characters are

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And characters are going to be letters, digits,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: special characters, spaces, and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's just going to count how many characters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are in a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I have the string s is equal to abc,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: remember a string is in quotation marks,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then if I write this expression len s here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: since it's an expression, it has a value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it evaluates to a certain value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And by definition, it's going to tell me

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what the length of the string is, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is three characters long.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Another thing that we can do on strings

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is since there are a sequence of characters,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I might want to get what character

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is at a certain position.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we do this using this fancy word called indexing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But pretty much what indexing into a string means

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is you're going to tell Python, I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: want to know the character at this certain position

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or at this certain index inside my string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So once again, let's use this string s is equal to abc.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And let's index into it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in computer science, we start from zero,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: counting by convention.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Notice we had a problem set zero in this class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python's no different.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in Python, you start indexing at position zero.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or you start indexing at zero.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first character in your string, we say,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is at position zero or at index zero.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The next character in the string is at index one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the next character in the string is at index two.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In Python, it turns out you can also

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: use negative numbers to index.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if you use, if you index into the string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with negative one, for example, that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means that you want the last character in the string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the last character in your string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is always going to be at position negative one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Second to last character is at negative two.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Third to last character is at negative three.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so on and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the way you index into a string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is with these square brackets here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this is the notation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I want the character at position zero or at index zero,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I say s, which is the string I want to index into.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then inside the square brackets,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I say what index I want.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So s at index zero is going to be the value a.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: s at index one is going to be the value b.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so on and so on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we can also do negative indexing as well.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you do try, I added this in here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if you do try to index into a string

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: beyond the limits of the string, and we can even

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: try this out just to show you that it's not

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the end of the world if we do that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If we have s is equal to a, b, c,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and we have s at position 20, for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Obviously, my string is only length three,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so what's at position 20?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I get an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I call this angry text here in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But really, the most relevant thing to note

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is these last couple of lines here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This tells you what line is problematic.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So s at position 20 has an issue.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this last line here tells me what actual error I have.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's an index error, which means

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm trying to index too far into the string,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because it only has three characters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's nice to be able to get a single character out

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of my string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But sometimes, I might want to get a substring.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I want to start at the first character

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and go halfway into the string, or I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: want to take a few characters in between,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or I want to skip every other letter,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or something like that in my string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I want to do this slightly more complicated interaction

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with strings, we call that slicing, slicing into a string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this notation here should seem a little bit familiar,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because we saw it last lecture when we did it with range.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We had a start, stop, and a step.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The notation was a little bit different,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because in range, we had open, closed parentheses and commas

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in between.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But except for that, this sort of works the same.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The start is the index starting from 0,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from where you want to slice into the string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The stop is the stop index.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're going to go up until stop minus 1

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and take that index.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the step is every how many letters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you wish to take.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is the full notation here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but sometimes you can not give it a third number in here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you only give it two numbers, then to Python,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that represents just the start and the stop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And by default, step is going to be 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And there's a lot of other things

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can do with strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can omit numbers and just leave colons in Python,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: just by definition, the way that whoever wrote slicing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: had decided, if you omit numbers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then it's going to be equivalent to these things here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we slice using square brackets, just like indexing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: except now we can give it two numbers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So with this string s, if we slice into the string s,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we start from index 3 and go up until index 6.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if we have a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, this is position 0, 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you just count.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So s, starting from 3 and going till 6,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to start here, 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's going to come up with d.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we're going to take e.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we're going to take f.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And since we're going until stop minus 1,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're not going to take g, because this is position 6,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and we're going until 6 minus 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The next one here, 3, 6, 2, is going every other one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we start at 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then we skip every other one.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we go d, but not e, and then f, and then stop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you do s and then nothing inside except colons,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: notice that you're going to have s and then nothing,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and then colon, nothing, colon, nothing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So nothing for start, nothing for stop, nothing for step.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's just going to evaluate to the string itself.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's the same as 0 to the length s going every step.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This one might actually be useful.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It reverses the string automatically for you.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So with this one little line here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can get the inverse of your string.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that's equivalent to that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the minus 1 represents starting from the end

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and going back every letter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then this one's a little bit more complicated,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but also not too bad.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So as we're doing these string slices,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: again, if you're unsure what something does,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: just type it into Spyder.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you might be surprised.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You might not be.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it's a good way to check yourself

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to make sure you're understanding what's happening.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, one thing I want to mention, and it's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: good to keep this in the back of your mind.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to come back to this as we

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: start talking about slightly more complicated object types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But strings are immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just keep this word in the back of your mind

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as we go through this class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And what I mean by this is that an actual string object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: once it's created, cannot be modified.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This might not mean anything right now.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But let me just draw a little something.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's say I have this string s is equal to hello.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Remember in the first lecture, we drew a diagram sort of

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: like this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This is my memory.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I have this object hello.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this object hello is bound to this variable s, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So now I can access the object hello using this variable s.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now you might think, well, since I

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can index into a string, I might be able to just say

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: something like s at position 0 is equal to y, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And that'll just change the little h into a y,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and I'll have a new object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Well, strings are immutable, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: means in Python you're not actually allowed to do this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it gives you an error if you do try to do that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If you want the variable s to point to the string y-e-l-l-o,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you could just say s is equal to y-e-l-l-o.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or you could do string operations like this.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this takes the y, and it concatenates it

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the string s, all of the elements

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: starting from position 1, which is e-l-l-o.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this makes y-e-l-l-o.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Now internally, what happens when I write this line is,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python says, OK, I'm going to break my bond

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with this original object hello.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to bind my string variable s

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the new object yellow.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this other old object still is in memory somewhere.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But it's an entirely different object that I've created here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Again, might not mean anything right now,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: but just keep this in the back of your mind.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Strings are immutable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the next thing I want to talk about

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is a little bit of recap on for loops.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to see how we can apply for loops very easily

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to write very nice readable code when dealing with strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So remember that for loops had a loop variable, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: My loop variable being this var here in this particular case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It could be anything you want.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this variable in this particular case

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: iterates over this sequence of numbers, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the very first time through the loop, var has a value of 0.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It does the expressions in the loop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Soon as they're done, var takes the value 1.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It does all the expressions in the loop.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then var takes the value 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it does that all the way up until 0, 1, 2.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the last time it goes around is with var is equal to 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And remember, we said that we can customize our range

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in order to start from a custom value

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to end at a different value and to skip certain numbers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So far, we've only been using for loops

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: over a sequence of numbers.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But actually, for loops are a lot more powerful than that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can use them to iterate over any sequence of values,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: not just numbers, but also strings.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here are two pieces of code, this one and this one here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: These two pieces of code both do the exact same thing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: To me, possibly to you, this one looks a lot more readable

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: than this one, just at a first glance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If I were to read this one just using the keywords

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and variables here, it would sound like broken English.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But you could decipher what I'm trying to say.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For a char in a string s, if the char is equal to i

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or a char is equal to u, print there is an i or a u.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sounds weird.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But you could probably tell what I was trying to do here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Whereas up here, it's a little more complicated

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to tell what I'm doing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You have to think about it a little bit.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For some index in this range of numbers,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: 0 through the length of the string s,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if s at position index is an i or s at position index is a u,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: print there is an i or a u.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Both of these codes just go through the string s.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And if it encounters a letter that's an i or a u,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: it's just going to print out this string here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But this bottom one is a lot more Pythonic.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's an actual word created by the Python community.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it just looks pretty.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You can tell what this code's supposed to do.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Whereas this one is a little bit harder to decipher.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's sort of an illustration of a for loop

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: over a sequence of characters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So char is going to be a loop variable still.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the loop variable, instead of iterating

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: over a set of numbers, is going to iterate over every character

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in s directly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And char is going to be a character.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It's going to be a letter.

chunks.text: So here's a more complicated example.

chunks.text: So given a problem, let's say, find the cube root of a number.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's say you can guess a starting value for a solution.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The guess and check method works if you're

chunks.text: able to check if your solution is correct.

chunks.text: So if your guess is originally 0,

chunks.text: you can say, is 0 cubed equal to the cube of whatever

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm trying to find the cube root of?

chunks.title: Lecture

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: No, right?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the solution is not correct.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If it's not correct, guess another value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Do it systematically until you find the solution,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: or you've guessed all of the possible values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You've exhausted all of your search space.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So here's very simple guess and check code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that finds the cube root of a number.
